newsitem.title: SWEDEN: AssiDoman says pulp price rise unlikely.
newsitem.headline: AssiDoman says pulp price rise unlikely.

text.p: Swedish forestry company AssiDoman on Friday said the planned pulp price rise to $610 a tonne from about $560 was unlikely.
AssiDoman's chief executive officer (CEO) Lennart Ahlgren also told Reuters in an interview that he sees a definite upturn in the sawn timber products market.
"We have now seen the definite upturn for sawn timber and timber," Ahlgren said. "In October, our saw milling operations showed black figures, which is a clear trend change."
But Ahlgren sees a risk for a setback for some paper grades in the first six months of 1997, following weak North American/Scandinavian (Norscan) pulp inventory figures, he said.
In November, Norscan inventories rose by a preliminary figure of 185,000 tonnes from October, forestry group Sodra Skogsagarna said on Thursday.
"If you could have shown falling figures, I would have been fairly convinced about possibilities to increase prices, but now I am sceptical," Ahlgren said.
"We must be prepared for not just pulp, but also certain paper grades turning downwards next year," Ahlgren said, adding that fine paper could be among the grades hurt.
Ahlgren said he did not think that the pulp price will fall below the current level of about $560 a tonne.
Also, he expected a recovery in the second part of 1997.
"The risks for setbacks we see during the first half (of 1997), I think we can recover during the second half," he said.
